Ah, if only words didn't exist... things would be easier, right?

When I first started playing, it took me a while to understand that these black silhouettes, merrily running about, were other people.
Simple, yet pure. Through movement, through emotes, an endearing expression of the good in all of us.
It made me want to befriend everyone I met.
It made me remember these simple moments of bonding in real life.

It made me realize the value of words.

Maybe we're too quick to resort to them. Maybe, if we listened carefully, we would find better ones.
Or maybe I'm overthinking it.

Whatever the case, dear reader, maybe one day our paths will cross.
And I will try to listen. Will you?

Over all devices I have almost 1000 hours in this game, and I've been playing since 2021.

It's difficult to properly this describe this game. The visuals are beautiful, the music is soothing and captivating, flying is fun, and just the general feel of it is something I haven't encountered in any game before. 

You can play it for 2h and just check it out. You can play through the ""main storyline"" and quit, and just experiencing that is worth it in of itself. The end sequence is one of the most beautiful things I have ever witnessed. You can continue playing, chat with players, enjoy and explore the new areas you unlock, and try to piece together some of the story that is only told through environmental storytelling. Or you can be like me and put 100rds of hours into it, because it is just so comforting and the gameplay loop really scritches something in your brain, and the few new things that get added are enough to keep you captivated. There is something for anyone that is curious about it.

I wouldn't listen too much to people that say this is p2w - there is nothing to win. You make your own goal in this game. Don't try unlocking everything - you will absolutely get burnt out, frustrated and think this is p2w. The only thing you get additionally are cute cosmetics and sometimes secret areas. But that's it. The entirety of the game is open to you, to socialize in, to ravel in the beauty of it. 

It's a special game. It's a piece of art you can glide through, and while ThatGameCompany has its issues, I feel it has been getting better during this year (2025). There is a lot of love put into this game that you can feel in many corners of it. Greed can never be completely wiped out of anything created by humans, don't let it taint the massive beauty that everything else is.

[h3] Is Sky Worth Playing? [/h3]

It depends. The game isn‚Äôt for everyone ‚Äî there‚Äôs no clear goal, no real progression. Some mechanics even tie the hands of new players who don‚Äôt have friends to help them enter certain areas or complete quests. Most of the enjoyment the game offers comes from talking to people and collecting cosmetics. Misantropes and socially anxious players likely won‚Äôt enjoy it, and completionists will probably burn out from the daily currency grind (unless they decide to pour their whole wallet into the game). Not to mention those who don‚Äôt like sitting around doing nothing or expect challenging quests. Sooner or later, the game becomes monotonous for many.

I went through the phase of ‚ÄúThis is the best thing I‚Äôve ever seen‚Äù to ‚ÄúThis feels like a second job‚Äù several times before I lost my account. Losing all the cosmetics I gathered over [i] four years [/i], including paid items, completely broke me. Only after a year-long break did I learn that the game was coming to PC.

So I returned. Not because I want to start from scratch, but because I want to change my approach.
The game truly is amazing. The world‚Äôs story might not be very deep, but it‚Äôs incredibly meaningful. [spoiler] ‚ÄúEvery ending is just a new beginning.‚Äù [/spoiler] And I never expected philosophy to appeal to me.

The sky here is diverse. It‚Äôs unique. Nowhere else will you find moments like the ones this game can give you, especially player interactions. These encounters are special, mostly thanks to how friendly the community is. Truly, this game is about friendship. And the biggest paradox is that you don‚Äôt need deep relationships with anyone to feel it. Sky suits both extroverts and introverts. The only thing you need is the desire to show genuine kindness. If you feel that this peaceful world is right for you, I‚Äôll give you just one piece of advice ‚Äî don‚Äôt kill your love for the game by grinding candles every day. This is a long review; my apologies in advance.

(NO SPOILER REVIEW)

I can tell, Sky: children of light it's one of the best games of this type I ever played, it's a bunch of incredible memories and experiences alongside amazing people, that's why I have dedicated over 1100 hours on this game. The art, the places, the missions, the music, but most importantly: THE PLAYERS; this is why I can enjoy this game so much! and that's why I'm spending my time writing this review (I hope it's worth it for you).

And with that already said, I'd like to point out the strengths and the weaknesses:

THE STRENGTH:

	It's a very chill game, you can basically do whatever you want (it's more fun with friends), talk, travel, discover, make challenges like hide and seek, do missions together, etc... It's the best game I have ever seen to meet new people, the community it's also the most healthy I ever experienced! 
	You always can get help and in general feeling when you play it's magical! in short words, it's one of the best options to relax after a very hard day. The developers every time add new content so it's hard to get bored and you have access to a good part of the content for free.

THE WEAKNESSES:

	In this section I'll start with the most obvious and important one... THE BUGS, every new up load it's a new kind of bugs... the game it's still playable but it can mess up with the experience sometimes... specially when you play with other people. 
	Also THE MICRO-TRANSACTIONS, unfortunately not all the content it's available for free and some of the items are just too expensive, many people cannot just afford all of them so normally if you are willing to pay you need to choose (not to mention you'll need to wait a while to see them available again). 
	To finish I also got THE CONNECTION PROBLEMS BETWEEN SERVERS; I play with friends that live in Asia and the connection problems (depends on the day) are usual, that of course could affect negatively the game experience.

To finish this review, I can tell you this game it's very enjoyable if you are looking for a calm, magical and anti-stress experience, but it's not perfect. I hope this review have been helpful and if you make it this far reading...

The initial experience of this game is defined by its commitment to beautifully executed non-verbal communication. Early on, observing the black silhouettes moving across the world‚Äîwhich are, in fact, other players‚Äîis a powerful realization. This interaction, facilitated purely through movement and simple emotes, strips away complexity and fosters a sense of profound, unadulterated connection. This fundamental design choice encourages a unique form of social bonding, echoing simple, genuine human interaction often overlooked in digital spaces. It highlights the power of observation and shared experience over explicit dialogue.

The accessibility of the experience is one of its strengths. New players can engage with it as a contained narrative, spending just a few hours. Completing the "main storyline" is highly recommended, as the final sequence stands as one of the most aesthetically and emotionally impactful moments in modern gaming. For those seeking depth, the game offers hundreds of hours of exploration. The environment richly narrates the lore, and the core gameplay loop provides a deeply comforting and consistently engaging experience, inviting prolonged immersion.

A necessary comment on the economy: while the game is not pay-to-win‚Äîas there are no competitive goals‚Äîthe acquisition of most unique, desirable cosmetics (especially seasonal items) for free-to-play players presents a significant, demanding grind. This requires a high degree of patience and commitment and can lead to frustration if the objective is unlocking every item. Players are advised to define their own progression goals to avoid burnout. Despite this demanding monetization structure, the game's performance is excellent and highly optimized. Furthermore, the developer's disposition and efficiency in handling support tickets are genuinely commendable and reliable.

This game wants your money. And if it can't have that, it'll gladly take your time.

For those that are familiar with That Game Company (TGC) and their original creation, Journey, Sky Children of the Light ironically betrays that games core value's in favor of commercial pursuit. Whereas Journey prioritized a contemplative experience of traveling at your own pace and enjoying the world around you, Sky immediately drops new players into the neverending rat race, your existence becoming a relentless grind that's driven by the fear of falling behind. 

In 2022, one of the creators  had criticized IAPs (in app purchases) for preying on negative emotions, stating that "...they appeal to our greed or fear of missing out..." And while I did not play during the time of this interview to verify the integrity of such a statement, the departure from it now in 2025 is laughable. It still wears the deceptively ethereal aesthetic that was also present in Journey, but it holds none of its sincerity. 

While new players are free to roam at their own pace, this game is essentially an open world chatbox that encourages meeting and helping new people. Befriending others isn't free, however. That will cost you your in-game resources. And if you'd like the ability to talk to someone, that will cost you even more. These resources are the crux of the issue with this game, as not only is the amount you are able to collect capped out daily, they are also needed to purchase the other (and in my opinion, main) driving force of this game, cosmetics. 

If you play for any amount of time in this game you will notice the cosmetics. Whether from other players, seasonal events, traveling spirits, or IAPs, the game is constantly showcasing  what's available. They will make it known to you how much time is left on certain events, what's available, and of course, they will lock the best looking cosmetics to IAPs. In no time, you'll find yourself planning months in advance for seasonal events, release cycles for potential returning cosmetics and rationing your resources so that you don't miss out on something you really want. The events are constantly following each other immediately after one ends, so there is little to no time to recuperate your losses when another one comes bounding up that trail.

But what does that leave you with? The desire to share is accompanied by caution and frugality. There is no longer time to connect, no time to chat, and for a game that is supposedly built around making connections, generosity becomes a luxury. 

An average spirit's cosmetics costs about 140 candles, the game's primary resource. The daily cap for earning candles is 20, which if you like to play less hyper-optimized like me, you can earn with about 2 hours of playtime. This meaning you'd have to play for a minimum of 14 hours if you wanted to buy all of this spirit's items. That does NOT INCLUDE the time it takes to establish a routine in which you learn to gather all of said candles. Now you  may not necessarily want all of a spirit's items, but in a worst case scenario I had a spirit where I bought out most everything of for 200 candles. Which is 20 hours of my time. Sometimes singular items cost 140 candles. There's one in game right now for 120. That's 12 hours split across 6 days of your time, for one, singular item. For the majority of the time I played this game, I was unemployed which is how I was able to make this feasible. But for anyone with school, work, or a busy home life, how is this sustainable? Only now after 9 months of unbroken playtime do I feel comfortable because the next spirit isn't going to break my candle bank. If this all sounds tiring to you though, you can always use your real life dollars to buy more candles!

When you are not actively grinding, the game will find other ways to waste your time. There's long, unskippable cutscenes such as one door animation that takes a staggering 50 seconds, camera pulls that another player activated that lasts 10 seconds, flights between areas. These scenes or moments aren't especially interesting either and you'll likely be experiencing them daily. The repetitive delays are constant.

To combat the time it takes to go from area to area whilst collecting candles, certain community efforts were made to help ease the grind. And every time the community has banded together to support one another, TCG has made their best efforts to shut it down. One method beloved by everyone allowed players to afk for a measly 10 minutes whilst you could simultaneously passively gather candles. It was a small mercy amongst the daily repetitive grind. TCG made sure to nip that in the bud. Another allowed you to cut 3-5 minutes of travel time between areas at a time. Since no fast travel methods exist, this was a lifesaver within a game that has constant long, uninteresting stretches of travel. TCG made sure to do away with that as well, not just once but several times! As it was harmless, what is the purpose for this other than to enforce some arbitrary rule they've created? TCG allows other unintended uses of traversal, such as chibi falling, so do they not realize their own hypocrisy? To me, the intention is clear. They want their players tired. They want fatigue, they want you burnt out from grinding, because when you are tired, you're more likely to buy. And that is the issue of it all really. This is not a game about connection. It doesn't encourage positive emotions like it claims, but preys on your burnout whilst the kind, patient players who continue to uplift each other in a system designed to wear them down carry its name.

Some reviews say to play it once, and never again. I personally wouldn't recommend you play it at all, if only for the fact that adding to the player count will give TGC a continued incentive to keep doing what they're currently doing, and have apparently [i] been [/i] doing way before I've joined.

It does genuinely hurt me to say this, too. At the core of the experience, it's a lighthearted and absolutely [i] gorgeous [/i] experience to go through. Flying feels absolutely phenomenal in Sky, and it's home to probably one of the most unique social systems I've ever seen in a game. Going from faceless strangers unable to communicate past gestures, all the way up to full-fledged friendships with unrestricted communication is honestly one of the most heartwarming experiences I could ever ask for. I do, with all my heart, love this game, even for what little I've played of it.

But the fact is that under the surface, past your first playthrough, that facade of a pristine utopian world, where everyone's happy and nothing goes wrong, quickly diminishes away once you realize that the game is so hyper-focused on draining your wallet on overpriced cosmetics, battle passes, FOMO, and even it's own core systems. It's a game that, despite it's charm, will always have one hand in your pocket while it regales you with it's bright, sunny atmosphere, and friendly playerbase.

Candles are Sky's main currency, and already it's being torn in two by being the both the money you use to buy cosmetics to express yourself, and also the currency you use to make and develop friendships. With your candle grind being hard-capped at a measly 20 candles a day, assuming you do a *full candle run* without burning out midway through, (With [i] single cosmetics [/i] costing up to 100+ candles each????) that means that you are stuck with the ultimatum of "Ignoring the grind, and focusing on making friends" or "Saving up your money to slowly chip away at that cape you want". [b] It's a system that cannibalizes itself in order to coerce you into buying candle packs. [/b]

Doing one will dip into the progress of another. Making friends and unlocking unrestricted chat between them will make your cosmetic grind even harder, on a game that's already being so heavily bogged down by its insane grind.

They are selling candle packs for actual money. There is a tangible value to these candles. [b] Friendships, in this social game, cost money. [/b] You can't even so much as [b] hug [/b] or even [b] chat [/b] outside of designated chatting areas, without it being tied to it's main form of monetization. You either make friends, become antisocial with other players for weeks on end in an attempt to save up candles, or fork up money in a vain attempt to have both.

This is depressing beyond belief. If someone like EA, Ubisoft, or any big corporation pulled this type of thing in one of their games there would be public outcry about it, and it blows my mind that the community is being so soft with TGC about this. EDIT: Now that I've played Sky for upwards of 80 hours (it was 19 when I first reviewed it), I thought I should update my review. It's more or less the same as before, but now with comments about their progression and "macro"transactions.

I don't think I've ever felt so much frustration with a game that tries to evoke a feeling of peace and tranquility. I want to like Sky because the premise is nice as a light, social MMO. The visuals are pleasant (if buggy) and the sounds are lovely. But the game itself feels so poorly made.

The new player experience is needlessly obscure. I had to look up their help guides online to understand the currencies and mechanics. Quests' reminder messages are too vague. Control is taken from you regularly by an inordinate amount of cutscenes, some of them triggered by other people halfway across the region, and they all last twice as long as they need to.

The camera may be the worst camera I've seen in gaming. It fights you at every turn. Even when I leave the thumbstick alone to let the camera do its own thing, it snaps in random directions for no apparent reason. It clips into walls. It focuses on random areas at times, filling your screen with a nearby boulder instead of the open plain that you're standing in. It moves away from your character to prioritize a cutscene even though you're in immediate danger of being attacked. Sky's been out since 2019 (almost seven years now) and they haven't been able to smooth it out in all that time.

The controls are poor and unpredictable. While trying to slowly walk, your character will suddenly sprint ahead or jump onto some nearby ledge that you weren't even walking toward. Your bursts of flight get ignored and consumed when trying to fly from ledges. When burning plants or lighting candles, your flame will regularly just not work. When flying you might get yanked around by a wind tunnel or forced into an odd direction for flying too deeply into clouds.

You're regularly transitioned between varying degrees of control. Sometimes you have full control of your flight and it feels great, but sometimes you're railroaded and can only coast slightly in each direction. Sometimes the game bugs out in some weird in-between because it can't decide whether you should be free or railroaded and you'll get stuck looping in a tunnel of clouds that you can't even see through because they block your screen. In most areas you start in hover mode, but in some areas you inexplicably start in glide mode. Your flight mode will arbitrarily be toggled, wrestling away your freedom of movement. When the game is 90% movement, you better make sure the movement is buttery smooth and actually enjoyable.

There are so many visual bugs. Awkward, jarring transitions between areas. Eyes falling out of characters' heads. Your character swapping between holding their left or right hand in the air when holding something above them. NPCs standing still for 5 seconds before you can interact (this happens with every single spirit you free). Something with their lighting, or maybe a lack of shadows, makes it difficult to perceive depth and distance. It looks like the game is still in development.

The final area is the worst frustration of all. The sound design is either buggy or intentionally poor, making it difficult to tell when shards are falling down on you from the storm. After going through multiple times, I now know that the shards aren't synced up with the "whooshing" sound of the storm. You just watch the explosions on the ground to time your movement. Shards will hit you despite clearly being behind cover. A single shard will randomly hit you when there's nothing else falling.

Now keep in mind, this was all about the gameplay. I haven't even gotten to the in-app purchases. It isn't readily apparent to a new player because of how vague everything is, but you are extremely limited in your progression as a F2P player.

Players are capped to a limit of roughly 20 candles (currency) per day and about 20 ascended candles (rare currency) per week. Realistically depending on your time investment, you'll get anywhere from 5 to 15 regular candles each day. This isn't too bad for the base game spirits.

Items and cosmetics from past seasons are no longer available. But for a limited time every two weeks, some spirits from the past seasons visit, making those items purchaseable once again (albeit for a steeper price than if you had played during that season). With these spirits, one cosmetic costs 40-60 candles. So if you earn 10 candles a day, you can buy a cosmetic in 5 days' time. Candles are also sold for money. The best value deal gets you 190 candles for $50. That can buy you 3-5 cosmetics.

More than that though, you have to unlock things at the bottom of the tree before you can get to the juicy cosmetics near the top. And you can't even see what's higher up the tree until you buy from the rows below. You get two blessings (one-use consumables) and an upgrade to that spirit's emote. So if you don't want those items, then for each spirit you're wasting about 10 candles and 3 hearts (9 candles) just to get to the top of their tree. But the "best" part about these spirits is that you can't even preview any of the cosmetics on your character. The in-game closet only lets you preview the current season's items. So if you buy something and don't like how it looks on you, you're out of luck (and 50 candles).

Speaking of the closet, this game has the worst interface when you're trying to buy something. You can't preview an item from the menu you're buying it from. You have to leave the spirit and find a closet, preview it there, and then go back to the spirit to actually buy it. Some things you can't preview at all, like props and spells. It's asinine.

To top it all off, the devs have made the most ironic system for socializing with others by making the friendship tree cost candles. Adding a friend costs 1 candle and unlocking the high five emote costs 1 candle. Only after that can you give them a gift of a heart for 3 candles (the typical price). But the problem is, you don't know how long this person is going to stick around for. They might quit the game next week. I've met so many fun players that I've gifted hearts to, but it costs me 5 candles every time I meet someone new. I want to befriend people, chat, and give gifts, but it leaves me broke so I can't buy anything myself. When veteran players help me and I try to gift them a heart, they decline and tell me to keep my candles because I'm going to need them. When vets are saying that, you know the game is a grind.

Climbing up the friendship tree, it costs another 2 + 3 candles to unlock the ability to freely chat with your friend. Further up it costs 3 candles and 1 ascended candle for the privelege of being allowed to buy microtransactions for your friend (lol). Most of the rest of the tree is emotes, but if you're interested in them it'll cost you 364 candles and 26 ascended candles for all of them.

It just doesn't make sense for a game that is (ostensibly) about socialization and connection. Make the tree progression based on how much time you spend with a friend or something. It's just a way to drain you of candles so you keep coming back to the daily grind.

If you've gotten this far, thanks for enduring my rant. The game is actually fun and unique in its premise, but the devs are predatory scumbags who don't deserve your money. They prioritize overpriced cosmetics and merch over actually fixing their game.
